posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked:
Right now, I have a simple test path that drives the robot backwards 2 meters before stopping, but the robot consistently stops around .3 or .25 meters away from the goal position as if the goal position was really 1.75 meters backwards instead of 2 meters backwards. I tried increasing/decreasing the p value and for some reason, decreasing the translation p value caused the robot to travel less distance and oscillate more. Decreasing the p value made the robot go a little further but didn’t help much either. Screen Shot 2023-03-28 at 7.56.46 PM 1920×1092 60.4 KB This is the path that I made. Any suggestions would be appreciated. Thanks!

Screen Shot 2023-03-28 at 7.56.46 PM 1920×1092 60.4 KB

Screen Shot 2023-03-28 at 7.56.46 PM 1920×1092 60.4 KB

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: It it possible for you to share your code, perhaps as a Github link?  Where does the robot think it ends up?  Are you using Field2d to show both the path and the odometry pose?

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked:
Ok, sorry. Here’s the link: 3984-2023/testingPID2 at ManualArmCOntrol · DesteoyerRZSS/3984-2023 · GitHub

I’m just using my the swerve auto builder included in the path planner lib Autonomus code is in Auton.Java

posts.name: Sam Mulvey
posts.cooked:
I would recommend using PPServer to visualize your odometry. It makes troubleshooting like this much easier.

It is important to distinguish whether the robot thinks it is close to the endpoint or not.

If the robot thinks it is close to its goal, try changing your wheel diameter. You should be able to tune this to get the appropriate distance repeatably.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Where and how do I launch pp server. I’ve heard of it before.

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan
posts.cooked:
sam.mulvey747:

If the robot thinks it is close to its goal, try changing your wheel diameter. You should be able to tune this to get the appropriate distance repeatably.

I think this is probably the case. You are using 4 as your wheel diameter in SwerveModule. I assume your wheels have some wear on them - I would take some calipers and re-measure your wheel diameter and use that value.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: We just replaced our treads with new treads before testing the path and it still was consistently off from the target so I don’t think that is likely.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
saikiranra:

I would take some calipers and re-measure your wheel diameter

I prefer to count encoder ticks over a measured distance, rather than relying on nominal wheel sizes and gear ratios.
